isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 2000 4000 and 8000 MODELS BUILT OCTOBER 1, 1998 AND AFTER - SPEEDOMETER/TACHOMETER, GAUGES AND WARNING LIGHTS - 9800 - OPERATION - GAUGES

svcsubproc.title: Speedometer/Tachometer Module
svcsubproc.para: The speedometer/tachometer output signals originate at the engine speed sensor (engine manufacturer's component) and at the vehicle speed sensor located at the transmission. These signals are sent to the engine Electronic Control Module (ECM). The engine ECM receives the input signals, processes them, and sends the signals in the form of serial data transmissions over the data link circuits to the speedometer/tachometer.
The engine ECM has been factory programmed with the information for various components a vehicle is equipped with, such as tire size, axle ratio, and engine model.

note.para: Any changes in vehicle components such as tire size, axle ratio, etc. requires the engine ECM to be reprogrammed and not the speedometer/tachometer microprocessor. Refer to engine manufacturer's service manual for information on reprogramming.

svcsubproc.para: The module receives battery power (key ON or OFF) from 10A fuse F4-A, circuit 13D.
The Speedometer/Tachometer module is grounded through circuit 11-GF through the cab harness to the left cab ground stud.

svcsubproc.title: Speedometer
svcsubproc.para: The vehicle speed signal is generated by the vehicle speed sensor (225) located on top of the transmission. This sensor contains a permanent magnet that creates a magnetic field. The sensor is mounted so that the magnetic field is repeatedly broken by a 16-tooth speedometer gear on the transmission. As the field is broken, an AC (alternating current) pulse is generated. This pulse is sent on circuits 97AK and 97AJ to the ECM (refer to Vehicle Speed Signal From ECM, below).

The signal from the vehicle speed sensor is used for cruise control, engine brakes, and other functions. The ECM processes the signal from the vehicle speed sensor and sends a signal in the form of a serial data transmission over the ATA data link circuit (a positive and negative pair of twisted wires) to the Speedometer/Tachometer module through connector (421). The signal is also present at the ATA data link connector (220) and vehicle speed can be read using an electronic service tool (EST). For additional information on the data link, refer to GROUP 08 - ELECTRICAL, Electronic Engine Controls, in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

The Speedometer/Tachometer control module processes the input signal and drives the 4-pin electronic speedometer gauge that plugs into the module. The speedometer and tachometer gauges are essentially the same except for the gauge markings.

svcsubproc.title: Tachometer
svcsubproc.para: The Cummins and Detroit Diesel electronic control systems include a sensor to determine engine speed, and supply the ECM with the information.

The ECM sends a signal in the form of a serial data transmission over the ATA data link circuit (a positive and negative pair of twisted wires) to the speedometer/tachometer module through connector (595). The signal is also present at the ATA data link connector (220), and engine speed can be read using an electronic service tool (EST) connected to the data link. For additional information on the data link, refer to GROUP 08 - ELECTRICAL, Electronic Engine Controls in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

The speedometer/tachometer control module processes the input signal and drives the 4-pin electronic tachometer gauge that plugs into the module. The speedometer and tachometer gauges are essentially the same except for the gauge markings.

svcsubproc.title: Odometer
svcsubproc.para: The odometer is a solenoid activated mechanical counter type unit driven by the speedometer/tachometer module microprocessor.

The speedometer/tachometer processor will advance the odometer in 1/10 mile steps, based on the input signal over the data link from the engine ECM. Tire revolutions per mile, and axle ratios are the major factors in determining the correct signal. The ECM must be properly programmed to reflect the vehicle configuration. Other factors that can affect tire revolutions per mile are tire manufacturing tolerances, tire load, tire inflation pressures, vehicle speed and tire wear. Refer to the proper engine service manual for ECM programming.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Oil Pressure Gauge
svcsubproc.para: The engine oil pressure gauge indicates the pressure of oil in the oil gallery during engine operation.
The gauge is a mechanical gauge, and works by direct pressure from the oil gallery, through a hose that is attached to the back of the gauge. It is mounted in the left gauge cluster.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Water Temperature Gauge
svcsubproc.para: The water temperature gauge indicates the temperature of the water/coolant in the engine and cooling system.

The water temperature circuit consists of two basic components: the cluster-mounted gauge and the thermistor sending unit. The sender controls the gauge reading, which indicates the water temperature. The gauge is a 3-pin electrically driven gauge that plugs into the left gauge cluster.

svcsubproc.title: Fuel Level Gauge
svcsubproc.para: The fuel level gauge indicates the amount of fuel in the fuel tanks.

The fuel level circuit consists of two basic components: the cluster-mounted gauge and the fuel tank sending unit. The sender controls the gauge reading, which indicates the fuel level. The gauge is a 3-pin electrically driven gauge that plugs into the right gauge cluster.

svcsubproc.title: Voltmeter
svcsubproc.para: The voltmeter gauge indicates the condition of the battery and/or charging system.

With the key switch on, but before starting the engine, the voltmeter will show the condition of the battery. With the engine running, at operating speeds, the gauge indicates the status of the charging system. The gauge is a 2-pin electrically driven gauge that plugs into the left gauge cluster.

svcsubproc.title: Rear Axle, Engine Oil And Transmission Oil Temperature Gauges
svcsubproc.para: The optional forward rear axle, rear rear axle, engine and transmission oil temperature gauges indicate the temperature of the affected axle, engine or transmission.

The forward rear axle, rear rear axle, engine oil and transmission oil temperature circuits consist of two basic components: the cluster-mounted gauge and a thermistor sending unit. The sender controls the gauge reading, which indicates the temperature of the axle or transmission. These gauges are 3-pin electrically driven and plug into the right gauge cluster.

svcsubproc.title: Pyrometer
svcsubproc.para: The pyrometer gauge indicates the temperature of exhaust gases leaving the engine.

The system includes a gauge, a control module located behind the center instrument panel, and a thermocouple in the exhaust pipe near the turbocharger. The gauge is a 3-pin electrically driven gauge that plugs into the left gauge cluster.

The exhaust thermocouple generates a very small voltage when heated by the exhaust gas. Voltage goes up as exhaust temperature goes up. The voltage is too small to drive a gauge so the thermocouple lead is connected to an amplifier. The thermocouple and leads are special wires, so if damaged, the thermocouple/lead assembly must be replaced as one assembly.
The pyrometer control module processes the signal from the exhaust thermocouple, and amplifies the signal. The higher signal then drives the pyrometer gauge.

svcsubproc.title: Exhaust Thermocouple
svcsubproc.para: The exhaust thermocouple generates a very small voltage when heated by the exhaust gas. Voltage goes up as exhaust temperature goes up. The voltage is too small to drive a gauge so the thermocouple lead is connected to an amplifier. The thermocouple and leads are special wires, so if damaged, the thermocouple/lead assembly must be replaced as one assembly.
The pyrometer control module processes the signal from the exhaust thermocouple, and amplifies the signal. The higher signal then drives the pyrometer gauge.

svcsubproc.title: Pyrometer Control Module (Amplifier)
svcsubproc.para: The pyrometer control module processes the signal from the exhaust thermocouple, and amplifies the signal. The higher signal then drives the pyrometer gauge.

svcsubproc.title: Air Pressure Gauges (Primary And Secondary)
svcsubproc.para: The air pressure gauges indicate the amount of air in the primary and reserve air tanks.
The gauges are mechanical and work by direct pressure from the air tanks. The gauges are mounted in the right gauge cluster.

svcsubproc.title: Air Cleaner Restriction Gauge
svcsubproc.para: The air cleaner restriction gauge shows how much air cleaner filter capacity has been used and how much remains.
This gauge is a mechanical gauge and works on a vacuum from the air cleaner. It is mounted either in the left gauge cluster or the farthest right wing panel.

svcsubproc.title: Transmission And Engine Oil Pressure Gauges
svcsubproc.para: These gauges show the oil pressure in these systems.

The gauges are mechanical and work by direct pressure from the affected system. The engine oil pressure gauge is located in the left gauge cluster. The transmission oil pressure gauge is located in the right gauge cluster.
